titleproper.value: Guide to the Louis Weinstock Papers and Photographs  <num>WAG.013</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Keri A. Myers (2009); Edited by Erika Gottfried to reflect the incorporation of nonprint materials and for compliance with DACS and Tamiment Required Elements for Archival Description (2013)

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-05-11T20:30:46</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

extent.value: in 3 record cartons, 2 manuscript boxes, 1 oversized flat box, and 2 oversized folders.

abstract.value: Louis Weinstock was born in Hungary in 1903 and emigrated to the United States in 1923. He settled in New York City and in 1925 joined the Painters' Union, Local 499. Weinstock became one of the leaders of the "Rank and File" movement in District Council 9 of the International Painters and Paperhangers. He fought for Social Security and initiated the drive for unemployment insurance. Weinstock also led the Rank-and-File painters caucus in a fight against corruption in the union, defeating the corrupt leadership of the infamous Lepke-Gurrah racketeer gang and getting elected to the office of Secretary-Treasurer. In 1951, he was charged with conspiring to violate the Smith Act while teaching a trade union class; he was found guilty and sentenced to three years in jail. Weinstock retired from the union in 1963 and died in 1994 from heart failure.

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Louis Weinstock Papers and Photographs; WAG 013; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
Donated by Louis Weinstock's children, Dr. John Weinstock and Susan Gould, in 1995. The accession numbers associated with this collection are 1995.028, 1995.029 and NPA.1998.008.

<list><item>Gersh, Adolph B., <title render="italic">Occupational Hazards and the Painter.</title>New York: New York District Council No. 9, B. of P. D. & P. of A., 1937.</item><item>Hall, Burton H., editor. <title render="italic">Autocracy and Insurgency in Organized Labor.</title>New Brunswick: Transaction Books, 1972.</item><item>Montgomery, John Flournoy. <title render="italic">Hungary: The Unwilling Satellite.</title>New York: The Devin-Adair Company, 1947.</item><item><title render="italic">The Struggle of the New York Painters for Human Conditions.</title>New York: District Council 9, Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators, and Paperhangers of America, No Date.</item><item>Zausner, Philip. <title render="italic">Unvarnished: The Autobiography of a Labor Leader</title>. New York: Brotherhood Publishers, 1941.</item></list>

The papers and photographs of Louis Weinstock document his life from the 1920s to his death in 1994. The collection includes personal artifacts as well as an extensive amount of material from his involvement with the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators, and Paperhangers. The collection is organized into seven separate series: personal, correspondence, writings, subject files, resource materials, ancillary materials, and photographs.

subject.value: May Day (Labor holiday) -- United States -- History.

type="inclusive">1920s-1980s</unitdate><unitdate normal="1940/1949" type="bulk">1940-1949</unitdate></did><scopecontent id="aspace_63b03751ac91f45580a589fb3ea6698e"><head>Scope and Content Note</head><p>Three-hundred-twenty-six black and white prints and 59 color prints, including images of these individuals: Warren K. Billings, "Mother" Ella Reeve Bloor, Fidel Castro, Joseph R. Curran, Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, Hugo Gellert, Gus Hall, Dorothy Healy, Fiorello LaGuardia, William O'Dwyer, Mike Quill, and Paul Robeson. Notable subjects depicted include May Day parades in New York City, and demonstrations protesting against the Korean War. Photographers include Hungarian immigrant photographers John Albok and Gabriel Hackett, Alexander Archer, and one photograph credited to A.H. Greene of the Film and Photo League.</p></scopecontent><c id="aspace_ref142" level="file"><did><unittitle>1920s?</unittitle><unitdate normal="1920/1929" type="inclusive">circa id="aspace_9f0716bb38e7fdb9f509b1c1c8d5809c"><head>General</head><p>This item was presented to Louis Weinstock in memory of his visit to the orphanage on November 4, 1966.  Captions are handwritten in Hungarian. Nineteen pages long (with photographs on both sides of the pages), it is arranged in original page order (indicated by an assigned page number written in pencil in square brackets on both sides of the pages).  The album also includes a dedicatory note that accompanied the album, and a sample page of the original interleaving papers in the album has been retained.</p></odd></c><c id="aspace_ref158" level="file"><did><unittitle>Oversized photographs - panoramic</unittitle><unitdate normal="1930/1949" type="inclusive">circa 1930-1950</unitdate><container id="aspace_e1203e2d4bbec4cf315ba397ab42eaf1" label="Photographs" type="Box">OS 001</container><container parent="aspace_e1203e2d4bbec4cf315ba397ab42eaf1" type="Folder">1</container></did></c><c id="aspace_ref161" level="file"><did><unittitle>Oversized photographs - miscellaneous</unittitle><unitdate normal="1930/1959" type="inclusive">circa 1930-1950; 1959</unitdate><container id="aspace_2f7bdc4aade239e237e776da4b166a8c" label="Photographs" type="Box">OS 001</container><container parent="aspace_2f7bdc4aade239e237e776da4b166a8c" type="Folder">2</container></did></c></c>
